https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/97304/ : FAILURE
Can you please describe your approach to fixing the issue here, along with why it's appropriate and what alternatives were considered.

To fix the PDR looping issue, while adding the entity association PDR, we are incrementing the record handle for every PDR which gets added in the path so that next PDR which gets added while adding entity association PDR should be with new record handle.
I wasn't able to think of another way to solve this issue. I will rework on this based on your suggestion to solve the issue.

I meant in the commit message, not just a reply to this comment thread.

Also if you're claiming something is fixed, please provide test cases to prevent regression of the behaviour.
Done
Hello Archana. I'd like some more explanation of your approach, as the patch itself seems like it is more complex than it needs to be.
This isn't used?
Signature of function entity_association_pdr_add is modified to take pointer to record handle. So added new variable record_handle.
Done
Why pass a pointer? Nothing consumes any value written?

entity_association_pdr_add function is called recursively for the child and sibling. 
https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/src/dsp/pdr.c#L923
https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/blob/main/src/dsp/pdr.c#L930

If new PDR gets added for child/sibling, the record handle which is needed for next PDR has to be incremented for next entity_association_pdr_add. The record handle is incremented inside this function
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/73465/1/src/dsp/pdr.c#843
If there are Physical and logical children for an parent entity we are creating separate PDRs for each of them, and incrementing the record handle.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/73465/1/src/dsp/pdr.c#867
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/73465/1/src/dsp/pdr.c#883
Done

Given the functions affected are static, can we instead return the record handle value as the result in the success case so we don't have an in-out pointer? Then the caller can increment the result as required.

Currently we are returning error code from those static functions. So can we safely consider that if the return value is ">=0" then its success case and record handle is returned and "<0" return value is considered as failure?
Yeah, that was my thought. What do you think? What's the maximum value for a record handle?
Record handle is a uint32 value.
Right, given its all internal, perhaps we change the static functions to return `int64_t` and avoid the need for a pointer for an in-out parameter.
Done
Ah, so for the record, this is the read that I missed previously.
Done
Can you please send a separate patch to return the result of `entity_association_pdr_add()`? We should not be unconditionally returning 0 here.
This change was needed as part of this commit. Updated the change.
Can you please rebase this change on top of the other one.
Done
Can you please add new abi dumps, as you are putting changes in stable libpldm api
ABI dumps are recreated only if signature of STABLE API changes.
My bad I missed out on function signature being unchanged hence no dumps needed.

😞

Have you seen [clang-tidy: Enable cppcoreguidelines-pro-type-reinterpret-cast](https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/libpldm/+/74448) ?

I'm planning to prevent further additions of `reinterpret_cast<>()`. Can we use the `msgbuf` APIs here instead?
I have used `msgbuf` APIs in one of the tescase. I will make similar changes to  another testcase once these changes are confirmed.
I've made some comments, hopefully they help clarify.
Done
This name feels a bit uninformative, are there better options?
Done

Please don't use the double-underscore functions, that was meant to be a hint that you shouldn't be using them. Use the macro wrapper instead, as that enforces type-safety.

```
pldm_msgbuf_extract_uint32(buf, record_handle_from_pdr);
```

Please also address the other instances of this below.

pldm_msgbuf_extract macro uses "_Generic", and cpp compilation fails to understand _Generic. Below is the error 
`in expansion of macro ‘pldm_msgbuf_extract’
 1449 |     pldm_msgbuf_extract(buf, record_handle_from_pdr);
      |     ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
../src/msgbuf.h:681:9: error: ‘_Generic’ was not declared in this scope
  681 |         _Generic((dst),                                                       `

That's not what I was suggesting though.

I suggested

`pldm_msgbuf_extract_uint32()`

and you've responded discussing

`pldm_msgbuf_extract()`.

I was not suggesting the latter (for the reason you outlined).

Please recognise that there are type-specific wrapper macros _in addition to_ the generic `pldm_msgbuf_extract()` macro.

There's a type-safety difference between

`pldm_msgbuf_extract_uint32()`

and

`pldm__msgbuf_extract_uint32()`

The latter drops all the type information by taking a `void *` argument, where the former still requires type information for size (but drops the alignment requirement for the type). You must use the former (macro wrapper, no double-underscore), and not the latter (static inline function, double underscores to make it feel like you shouldn't use it).
Done
Why define `skip_data_size`? We can instead use `sizeof(...)` in its place in the function call arguments.
Done
Please use `pldm_entity_association_tree_destroy_check()`.
Done
Can we add a CHANGELOG entry in the modified part?
Done

Can you please add a `Fixes:` tag?

Also, given this is a fix for (library) user-facing behaviour it needs an entry in the changelog.
Done
Hi Archana, thanks for the improvements. I have some more comments inline. Do note the comment about the change to the `pldm_msgbuf_extract_*()` APIs, it simplifies things slightly.
This must be `ASSERT_NE()`. Otherwise the test case will proceed, and you'll deref a `nullptr`.
Done
`ASSERT_NE()` again.
Done
`ASSERT_NE()`
Done
`ASSERT_EQ()` - executing beyond this point in the case of a failure is meaningless and may lead to UB.
Done

Note that I've just submitted https://github.com/openbmc/libpldm/commit/e5f125385e237ed4e7398acd8b67181cd18db745 which helps out with the ergonomics of these extraction functions. The impact on this patch is that you'll need to remove all the "address-of" operators here, so:

```
pldm_msgbuf_extract_uint32(buf, &record_handle_from_pdr);
```

becomes

```
pldm_msgbuf_extract_uint32(buf, record_handle_from_pdr);
```
Done
Done
Do we not have a struct declared somewhere that contains all these members? Must we really declare individual variables for them?
Done
Need an `ASSERT_EQ(pldm_msgbuf_validate(...), 0);` between the last extract call and the first `EXPECT_EQ()` here.
Done
Need to call `pldm_msgbuf_destroy()` before reinitialising over the top of the `buf` struct.
Done
Hi Archana, thanks for the rework so far, the conversion of the tests to the msgbuf APIs helps a lot. However, they're still far to difficult to follow. I've left some requests inline.
Why are you defining these inside the function scope? Why not lift them out, because I think you're using the same definitions (repeated) below.
Done
Firstly, thank you for converting the buffer parsing to use the msgbuf APIs. It's much easier to have confidence that we're not doing wildly inappropriate things wrt the object storage.
Acknowledged

This should rather be:

```
ASSERT_EQ(pldm_msgbuf_destroy(buf), 0);
```

And remove the `pldm_msgbuf_destroy(buf)` call on line 1550.
Done

Rather than this, can we instead define a static function that tests for equality of two instances of `struct pldm_association_pdr_test` and then EXPECT_EQ() on the result of the function call?

Then you can reuse all the logic without all the tedium.
Done

Is this not functionally equivalent to what's between lines 1512-1532? I'm struggling with the tedium.

Can you please pull this out to a static function defined in the test case? From there, use it in all circumstances where it's appropriate.
Done

`pldm_msgbuf_destroy(buf)` on line 1603 must be here instead, and it must also be of the form:

```
ASSERT_EQ(pldm_msgbuf_destroy(buf), 0);
```
Done

Unfortunately I'm struggling to understand exactly what properties this test is trying to demonstrate. It's too tedious for me to comprehend in detail, and seems to have too much going on.

Can you please write down the list of properties your trying to demonstrate are upheld?

From there we can think about whether we can split this test.

In the test TEST(EntityAssociationPDR, testPDR), we are testing entity association PDRs built by using function pldm_entity_association_pdr_add.
I wanted to test entity association PDRs build by using pldm_entity_association_pdr_add_from_node_with_record_handle function. So I have taken same data as that of "testPDR" and created new testcase.

The only thing I could see from testcase is that it involves multi level entity tree, with different association(physical/logical) combinations.

I am not sure how to split it.
Hi Archana, I've left a few more comments on the test cases. Please try to apply the patterns everywhere they're appropriate to reduce the tedium.
We should create a function that does all this, right? And call it where necessary?
Done
Same for this?
Done
compareEntityAssociationPDR()?
Done
compareEntity()?
Done
compareEntity()?
Done
compareEntity()?
Done
These are all static functions, and not part of the public library API, right? Can you please make that clear in the text? Otherwise this sounds like an ABI break.
Please remove this blank line.
Hi Archana, thanks for the improvements. I've left another round of comments as I still think it's possible to reduce the tedium of the tests. I also have some queries on the implementation.
This isn't right. None of this should have been deleted.

This shouldn't have been deleted either.

I assume this is a bad merge-conflict resolution?
This needs an underflow check.
This needs an overflow check.

Hmm, is this an error case though?

I think it would be a good idea to add a comment here explaining the behaviour.
This needs an overflow check.
This seems like a strange condition. Can we please have some documentation?
This needs an overflow check.
This seems odd. Why are we doing this? This should be the responsibility of the caller.
Again here?
So it occurs to me now that this might be better as `operator==()` (possibly implemented by `operator<=>()`?) on the associated struct?
As above.

Given that we know how many children are expected, I think we can integrate all this together and make our lives a little less clumsy. It may be that you end up merging the implementation of `getEntity()` into a loop over `.num_children` in the `getAssociationPdrDetails()` implementation.
This should be `pldm_msgbuf_destroy_consumed()`?

Can you pull this definition out and make it a `static constexpr const ...`? That way it will look less ugly but still hopefully allow the compiler to think about it a bit.

Please apply this approach for any similar remaining instances in the patch.
Does the tree need to be so complex? Can we simplify it and still demonstrate the required properties?
See the suggestion on line 1556. It should help here, and in each of the instances below.
